They display their creations to each other."Behold, my star picture," Lily shares. "It\'s bright and shiny.""Check out my heart picture," Ben counters. "It\'s warm and sweet."They beam with pride and embrace one another. Their nervousness has dissipated, and they relish their time with the stickers.', 1)
('Lily and Tom liked to collect things. They had a big box full of shells, rocks, feathers, and stickers. One day, they found a map in a book. It had a picture of a treasure chest and a red X."Let\'s follow the map and find the treasure!" Lily said."OK, but we need to be clever. The map has clues and riddles," Tom said.They took the map and went outside. They looked at the first clue. It said: "Go to the place where you swing and slide." They knew it was the playground. They ran there and looked for the next clue.The next clue said: "Look under the thing that has four legs and a tail." They thought hard. They saw a dog, a cat, a horse, and a bench. They decided it was the bench. They lifted it and found the third clue.The third clue said: "Count the flowers that are yellow and blue. Add them together and that\'s the number you need." They counted the flowers in the garden. There were six yellow ones and four blue ones. They added them and got ten.They looked at the map again. It showed a big tree with a hole. Next to the hole was a red X. They ran to the tree and looked inside. They saw a shiny treasure chest. They opened it and found lots of coins, jewels, and toys."Wow, we found the treasure!" Lily said."We are so clever!" Tom said.They hugged and cheered. They decided to share the treasure with their friends. They were very happy. They loved to collect things.', ' Present Tense:Lily and Tom love collecting things. They have a big box filled with shells, rocks, feathers, and stickers. Today, they discovered a map in a book. ('Ben and Lily were playing with their toys in the living room. They liked to pretend that they were tiny and their toys were big. They used a frame from a picture to make a door for their toy house."Knock, knock," Ben said, tapping on the frame. "Can I come in?""Of course, you can," Lily said, opening the frame. "You are very polite. Do you want some tea?""Yes, please," Ben said, sitting on a cushion. Lily poured some water from a bottle cap into a thimble. They pretended to sip their tea and chat.Suddenly, they heard a loud noise. It was their mom, coming home from work. She saw the frame on the floor and picked it up."Oh, what a nice frame," she said. "I wonder where it came from. I think I\'ll hang it on the wall."She did not see Ben and Lily inside the frame. They were too small. They shouted and waved, but their mom did not hear them."Help, help!" Ben cried. "We are in the frame!""How did we shrink?" Lily asked. "We need to get out!"They looked around and saw a window in the frame. They ran to it and pushed it open. They saw a bird outside. They hoped it would not eat them."Maybe we can fly with the bird," Ben said. "Maybe it will take us to our mom."They climbed on the bird\'s back and held on tight. The bird flew away with them. They hoped it would not fly too far. They wanted to go back to their mom and their toys. They wanted to be big again.', ' Present Tense:Ben and Lily play with their toys in the living room. ('Tim and Jen are twins. They like to play with cars and trucks. They have many cars and trucks in their room. They make noises like vroom and beep.One day, mom says, "We are going to the park. Get ready." Tim and Jen are happy. They love the park. They want to bring their cars and trucks. They put some in a bag.Mom takes them to the car. She says, "I have a surprise for you. We have a new driver today. His name is Bob. He is very nice. Say hello to Bob."Tim and Jen look at Bob. He is sitting in the front. He has a big nose, a big beard, and a big hat. He smiles at them. He says, "Hello, Tim and Jen. I am Bob. I am your driver today. Are you ready to go to the park?"Tim and Jen think Bob is ugly. They do not like his nose, his beard, and his hat. They do not say hello. They hide behind mom. They whisper, "Mom, we do not like Bob. He is ugly. Can we have another driver?"Mom says, "Shh, Tim and Jen. That is not nice. Bob is not ugly. He is different. He is a good driver. He will take us to the park safely. You should be polite and friendly. Say hello to Bob."Tim and Jen feel bad. They do not want to be rude. They peek at Bob. He still smiles at them. He says, "Do you like cars and trucks? I see you have some in your bag. I like cars and trucks too. I have some in my hat. Do you want to see?"Tim and Jen are curious. They like cars and trucks. They nod. Bob takes off his hat. He shows them his cars and trucks. They are small and colorful. He says, "These are my cars and trucks. I bring them with me everywhere. They are my friends. Do you want to play with them?"Tim and Jen are surprised. They think Bob is funny. They like his cars and trucks. They say, "Yes, please. Can we play with them?" They take some from his hat. They make noises like vroom and beep.Bob says, "Sure, you can play with them. But be careful. Do not lose them. They are very special to me." He puts his hat back on. He says, "Now, let\'s go to the park. Are you ready?"Tim and Jen say, "Yes, we are ready. Thank you, Bob. You are a nice driver. And you are not ugly. You are different. And we like different." They smile at Bob. They hold their cars and trucks. They are happy.Mom says, "That\'s good, Tim and Jen. I am proud of you. You are learning to be kind and respectful. And you are making a new friend. Bob is a good driver. And he is a good person. And he has a good hat." She smiles at Bob. She says, "Thank you, Bob. You are a great driver. And you have a great hat." She buckles up. She says, "Now, let\'s go to the park. And have some fun."', ' Present Tense:Tim and Jen are twins. They enjoy playing with cars and trucks. They have numerous cars and trucks in their room. They make noises like "vroom" and "beep."Mom announces, "We\'re heading to the park. Get ready." Tim and Jen are thrilled. They adore the park. They wish to bring their cars and trucks. They select some and put them in a bag.Mom escorts them to the car. She shares, "I have a surprise for you. Today, we have a new driver. His name is Bob. He is very kind." Tim and Jen glance at Bob, who is sitting in the front. He sports a large nose, a thick beard, and a big hat. He greets them warmly, "Hello, Tim and Jen. I\'m Bob. I\'ll be your driver today. Are you ready to go to the park?"Tim and Jen find Bob unattractive. They don\'t respond. They hide behind mom. They whisper, "Mom, we don\'t like Bob. He\'s ugly. Can we have another driver?"Mom hushes them, "Shh, Tim and Jen. That\'s not nice. Bob isn\'t ugly. He\'s different. He\'s an excellent driver. He\'ll take us to the park safely. Be polite and friendly. Greet Bob."Feeling guilty, Tim and Jen don\'t want to be impolite. They peek at Bob, who continues to smile at them. He asks, "Do you both enjoy cars and trucks? I notice you have some in your bag. I do too. Shall we play with them?"Tim and Jen are intrigued. They appreciate cars and trucks. They nod. Bob removes his hat, revealing his collection of small, colorful cars and trucks. He says, "These are my cars and trucks. I bring them everywhere. They\'re my friends. Would you like to play with them?"Tim and Jen are astonished. They find Bob amusing. They agree, "Yes, please. May we play with them?" They select some from his hat and make "vroom" and "beep" noises.Bob grants their request, "Of course, you may play with them. But be careful. Don\'t lose them. They\'re very special to me." He puts his hat back on and says, "Now, let\'s go to the park. Are you both ready?"Tim and Jen affirm, "Yes, we\'re ready. Thank you, Bob. You\'re a nice driver. And you\'re not ugly. You\'re different. And we like different." They smile at Bob. They clutch their cars and trucks. They\'re content.Mom approves, "That\'s wonderful, Tim and Jen. I\'m proud of you. You\'re learning to be kind and respectful. And you\'re making a new friend. Bob is an excellent driver. And he\'s a wonderful person. And he has a fantastic hat." She smiles at Bob. "Thank you, Bob. You\'re an outstanding driver. And you have an outstanding hat." She fastens their seatbelts. "Now, let\'s go to the park and have some fun."', 1)
('Tom and Mia were friends who liked to play outside. One day, they saw a big tree with many branches. Tom wanted to climb the tree and see how high he could go. He said to Mia, "Let\'s climb the tree! It will be fun!"Mia was fearful of the tree. She thought it was too tall and dangerous. She said to Tom, "No, I don\'t want to climb the tree. I\'m scared. What if we fall?"Tom said, "Don\'t be scared. I will help you. Climbing the tree will make us strong and brave. We will have power over the tree."Mia was not sure, but she wanted to be strong and brave too. She agreed to climb the tree with Tom. They held hands and started to climb. They climbed slowly and carefully, looking for places to put their feet and hands.They climbed higher and higher, until they reached a big branch. They sat on the branch and looked around. They saw the sky, the birds, the flowers, and the other trees. They felt happy and proud. They had climbed the tree!They smiled at each other and said, "We did it! We climbed the tree! We are strong and brave! We have power over the tree!"They hugged and decided to climb down. They climbed down slowly and carefully, until they reached the ground. They ran to their parents and told them what they had done. Their parents were happy and proud too. They praised Tom and Mia for their courage and skill.Tom and Mia felt good. They had overcome their fear and had a new adventure. They had learned something new and had fun. They had climbed the tree!', ' Present Tense:Tom and Mia are friends who enjoy playing outside. Today, they spot a large tree with numerous branches. Tom gets excited and suggests, "Let\'s climb this tree! It will be fun!" Mia feels apprehensive, thinking it\'s too tall and dangerous. She responds, "I don\'t want to climb the tree. I\'m scared. What if we fall?" Tom reassures her, "Don\'t be scared. I\'ll help you. Climbing the tree will make us strong and brave. We\'ll have power over it."Mia hesitates but desires to be strong and brave as well. She agrees to climb the tree with Tom. They join hands and begin their ascent. They move slowly and cautiously, seeking secure footing and handholds.They progress higher and higher, reaching a large branch. They sit down and take in the view. They observe the sky, birds, flowers, and other trees. They feel elated and proud. They\'ve conquered the tree!They exchange smiles and exclaim, "We did it! We climbed the tree! We\'re strong and brave! We have power over the tree!" They embrace and decide to descend. They descend gradually and carefully, eventually returning to the ground. They rush to their parents to share their achievement. Their parents are pleased and proud. They commend Tom and Mia for their courage and skill.Tom and Mia feel accomplished. They\'ve conquered their fear and embarked on a new adventure. They\'ve learned something new and had fun. They\'ve climbed the tree!', 1)
('Ben and Lily went to the park with Mom. They saw a huge pond with many ducks. Ben and Lily liked ducks. They wanted to feed them."Mom, can we give them some bread?" Lily asked."Sorry, sweetie, we don\'t have any bread. But we have some olives. Do you think they will like olives?" Mom said."Let\'s try!" Ben said. He took an olive from Mom\'s bag and threw it into the pond. A duck saw the olive and swam to get it. It picked up the olive with its beak and ate it."Yay! The duck likes olives!" Ben cheered."Me too! Me too!" Lily said. She took another olive and threw it into the pond. Another duck swam to get it. It also ate the olive."Wow! The ducks love olives!" Lily said."Can we swim with the ducks, Mom?" Ben asked."No, honey, the pond is too deep and cold for you. And the ducks might not like it. They need their space. But you can watch them swim and quack. They are very happy." Mom said."Okay, Mom. We will watch them. They are very cute." Ben said."Yes, they are. And you are very kind to share your olives with them." Mom said.Ben and Lily smiled. They sat on the grass and watched the ducks swim and eat olives. They had a lot of fun at the park.', ' Present Tense:Ben and Mom, Lily and I, go to the park. We see a large pond filled with many ducks. Ben and Lily enjoy ducks. They desire to feed them."Mom, can we give them some bread?" Lily asks."Sorry, sweetie, we don\'t have any bread. But we have some olives. Do you think they will like olives?" Mom suggests."Let\'s try!" Ben exclaims. He takes an olive from Mom\'s bag and tosses it into the pond. A duck spots the olive and swims towards it. The duck picks up the olive with its beak and eats it."Yay! The duck likes olives!" Ben cheers."Me too! Me too!" Lily echoes. She throws another olive into the pond. Another duck approaches and consumes it."Wow! The ducks love olives!" Lily marvels."Can we swim with the ducks, Mom?" Ben queries."No, honey, the pond is too deep and cold for you. And the ducks might not like it. They need their space. But you can watch them swim and quack. They are very happy," Mom explains."Okay, Mom. We will watch them. They are very cute," Ben agrees.We sit on the grass and observe the ducks swim and eat olives. We have a wonderful time at the park.', 1)
('Tim and Sam are playing with blocks. They like to build towers and houses and cars. Tim has a red block and Sam has a blue block. They want to make a big tower."Let me add my block to your block," Tim says. He puts his red block on top of Sam\'s blue block."No, I don\'t like that," Sam says. He pushes Tim\'s block away. "I want to add my block to your block."They both try to add their blocks to each other\'s blocks. They start to fight. They pull and push and shout."Stop it, stop it!" Mom says. She comes to see what is wrong. She sees the blocks on the floor. She sees Tim and Sam crying."What are you doing?" Mom asks. "Why are you fighting?""We want to add our blocks," Tim says."But we don\'t like the same colors," Sam says.Mom picks up a yellow block. She shows it to Tim and Sam."Look, this is a useful block," Mom says. "It can make your tower more colorful. It can also make a flame for your car. Do you want to try?"Tim and Sam nod. They wipe their tears. They take the yellow block from Mom. They take turns to add it to their blocks. They make a tall tower with a red, blue and yellow block. They make a car with a yellow flame. They smile and hug."Thank you, Mom," Tim and Sam say. "You are useful too."', ' Present Tense:Tim and Sam play with blocks. They enjoy building towers, houses, and cars. He places his red block on Sam\'s blue block."I don\'t prefer that," Sam objects. He pushes Tim\'s block away. "I want to add my block to yours."Both children try to add their blocks to each other\'s. A fight ensues. They pull, push, and shout."Stop it! Stop it!" Mom calls out. She enters the room to investigate. She observes the blocks on the floor and the crying children."What\'s going on?" Mom inquires. "Why are you two fighting?""We want to add our blocks," Tim explains."But we don\'t like the same colors," Sam adds.Mom picks up a yellow block. She presents it to Tim and Sam. "This block is useful," she says. "It can make your tower more colorful. It can also create a flame for your car. Would you like to try?"Tim and Sam nod. They wipe their tears. ('Anna and Ben are playing with their baby brother, Sam. Sam is very small and cute, but he is also very persistent. He wants to grab everything he sees, even if it is not his."Look, Sam, this is a ball. You can roll it and bounce it," Anna says, showing him a red ball. She rolls it to him gently, and he smiles and tries to catch it."No, Sam, this is a book. You can read it and learn new words," Ben says, holding a colorful book. He opens it and points to a picture of a dog. "This is a dog. It says woof-woof."Sam reaches for the book, but Ben pulls it away. "No, Sam, this is mine. You have the ball."Sam frowns and starts to cry. He does not want the ball. He wants the book."Ben, don\'t be mean. Share with Sam. He is just curious," Anna says, taking the book from Ben. He thinks Ben will like it too."Sam, leave me alone. I don\'t want the book. I want the ball," Ben says, pushing Sam away.Sam does not give up. He keeps crawling and laughing. She knows they love each other too, even if they fight sometimes. She decides to join them and play with the ball and the book. She thinks they will have more fun together.', ' Present Tense:Anna and Ben play with their baby brother, Sam. Sam is small and cute, but persistent. ('Lily liked to splash in the water. She had a big tub in her room with many toys. She liked to make waves and bubbles and sing songs. Sometimes her mom or dad would join her and splash with her.One day, Lily had to go to the office with her mom. Her mom had to work on her computer and talk to people. Lily had to be patient and quiet. She brought some books and crayons, but she soon got bored. She wanted to splash in the water.She saw a big bottle of water on a table. It looked like fun. She went to the table and tried to open the bottle. But it was too hard. She pushed and pulled and twisted, but nothing happened. She got angry and kicked the bottle.The bottle fell off the table and broke on the floor. Water splashed everywhere. Lily was surprised and scared. She heard her mom shout, "Lily, what did you do?"Lily started to cry. She ran to her mom and hugged her. Her mom was wet and angry, but also worried. She said, "Lily, you can\'t splash water in the office. It\'s not safe. You could hurt yourself or others. You have to be patient and listen to me."Lily said, "I\'m sorry, mom. I wanted to splash in the water. I like to splash in the water. Can we go home and splash in the water?"Her mom sighed and said, "Maybe later, Lily. But first we have to clean up this mess. And then we have to say sorry to the people in the office. Can you do that?"Lily nodded and said, "Yes, mom. I can do that. I love you, mom."Her mom smiled and said, "I love you too, Lily. But next time, please don\'t splash water in the office."', ' Present Tense:Lily likes to splash in the water. She has a big tub in her room filled with many toys. ('Sara and Ben are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big dog. The dog is not nice. It barks and runs at them. Sara and Ben are scared."Help!" Sara cries. "The dog is bad!""Run!" Ben says. "We need to hide!"They run to a big tree. They climb up the tree. The dog cannot climb. It stays under the tree. It barks and jumps. Sara and Ben hug each other. They are not happy."Will the dog go away?" Sara asks."I don\'t know," Ben says. "But we are fine. We are together. We are unite.""What is unite?" Sara asks."Unite means we are one. We are strong. We are friends," Ben says.Sara smiles. She likes Ben. She likes unite. She says, "Yes, we are unite. We are friends. We are fine."They wait for the dog to leave. They hope someone will come and help them. They stay in the tree. They are unite. They are fine.', ' Present Tense:Sara and Ben are friends. We like to play in the park. Today, we see a big dog. We are together.""What is unite?" I inquire. "Unite means we are one. We are strong. We are friends," Ben explains.I smile. I like Ben. I like the feeling of being unite. "Yes, we are unite. ('Lily and Ben were friends who liked to play in the garden. They liked to look at the flowers that had many colors and smells. They liked to touch the soft petals and the green leaves. They liked to pretend they were bees and butterflies.One day, they saw a new flower that they had never seen before. It was big and white and had a long stem. It looked like a bell. Lily and Ben wanted to see it closer. They ran to the flower and bent down to smell it."Wow, it smells so sweet!" Lily said. "I wonder what it is.""Maybe it is a magic flower," Ben said. "Maybe it can make wishes come true."They both closed their eyes and made a wish. Lily wished for a new doll. Ben wished for a new bike. They opened their eyes and waited for their wishes to come true.But nothing happened. The flower did not change. It did not give them anything. It only made a loud noise. It was not a flower at all. It was a trap. It was a snake that looked like a flower. It had been waiting for someone to come close. It had been waiting to bite.The snake bit Lily and Ben on their arms. It hurt a lot. They screamed and cried. They tried to run away, but they were too slow. The snake bit them again and again. It had poison in its teeth. The poison made them feel sick and sleepy. They fell to the ground and did not get up.The garden became gloomy. The sun hid behind the clouds. The wind blew the petals away. The other flowers did not bloom. They closed their buds and waited for the night. They were sad and scared. They had lost their friends. They had been fooled by the snake. They wished they had never seen the white flower. They wished they had never made a wish.', ' Present Tense:Lily and Ben play in the garden, enjoying the colorful and fragrant flowers. They touch the soft petals and green leaves, pretending to be bees and butterflies.Today, they discover a new flower. It\'s big, white, and has a long stem, resembling a bell. They approach it, curious."This flower smells so sweet!" Lily exclaims. "What could it be?" asks Ben."Maybe it\'s a magic flower," Ben suggests. "Maybe it grants wishes."They both close their eyes and make their wishes. Lily wishes for a new doll, Ben for a new bike. They open their eyes, waiting.But nothing happens. The flower remains unchanged. It emits a loud noise instead. It\'s not a flower at all. It\'s a snake, disguised as a flower.The snake bites Lily and Ben on their arms. The pain is intense. They scream and cry, trying to run away. But they\'re too slow. The snake bites them again and again, its venomous teeth causing them to feel sick and drowsy.They fall to the ground, unconscious. The garden grows gloomy. The sun hides behind the clouds. The wind blows the petals away. The other flowers close their buds and wait for night. They\'re sad and scared, having lost their friends to the snake\'s deception. They regret their encounter with the white flower. They regret their wishes.', 1)
('Lila and Max were best friends. They liked to play together at the park. One day, they saw a big tree with green balls on it. They wondered what they were."Let\'s pick one and see," Max said. He climbed the tree and grabbed a green ball. He threw it to Lila. She caught it and looked at it. It was hard and bumpy."What is this?" Lila asked."I don\'t know. Maybe it\'s a toy," Max said.They tried to roll it, bounce it, and kick it. But it was not fun. It was too heavy and dull."Maybe we can open it," Lila said. She found a rock and hit the green ball with it. It cracked and showed a soft green inside and a big brown seed."Wow, look at that!" Max said. He climbed down and joined Lila. They touched the green inside. It was creamy and smooth."Can we eat it?" Lila asked."I don\'t know. Maybe we should ask someone," Max said.They saw a lady walking by with a dog. They ran to her and showed her the green ball."Excuse me, miss. What is this?" Max asked.The lady smiled and said, "That\'s an avocado. It\'s a fruit. You can eat it. It\'s very good for you. And very popular too. Many people like it.""Really? Can we try it?" Lila asked."Sure, why not. But you have to share it. And don\'t eat the seed. It\'s too hard," the lady said.She gave them a spoon and helped them scoop out the green inside. They tasted it. It was mild and buttery."Mmm, this is yummy," Lila said."I like it too," Max said.They ate the avocado and thanked the lady. They felt happy and full.They decided to keep the seed and plant it in the park. Maybe they could grow more avocados and share them with their friends.They settled on a spot near the tree and dug a hole. They put the seed in the hole and covered it with dirt. They watered it with their water bottles."Maybe one day, we\'ll have our own avocado tree," Lila said."That would be awesome," Max said.They hugged and smiled. They were best friends. And they loved avocados.', ' Present Tense:Lila and Max play at the park together. They discover a tree with green balls. Max suggests they try one. He climbs the tree, grabs a green ball, and throws it to Lila. She catches it and examines it. It\'s hard and bumpy.They ponder what it is. "Let\'s try to open it," Lila suggests. She finds a rock and cracks the green ball open. The inside is soft and green with a large brown seed."Wow, look at that!" Max exclaims, joining Lila. They touch the green inside, which is creamy and smooth."Can we eat it?" Lila asks. "Maybe we should ask someone," Max replies.A lady with a dog passes by. They approach her and show her the green ball. "Excuse me, ma\'am. What is this?" Max queries.The lady smiles and responds, "That\'s an avocado. It\'s a fruit. You can eat it. It\'s good for you and popular too. Many people like it.""Really? Can we try it?" Lila inquires.The lady hands them a spoon and assists them in scooping out the green inside. They taste it and find it mild and buttery."Mmm, this is delicious," Lila says. "I agree," Max concurs.They thank the lady and feel happy and satisfied. They decide to keep the seed and plant it in the park. They choose a spot near the tree and dig a hole. They place the seed in the hole, cover it with dirt, and water it with their water bottles."Maybe one day, we\'ll have our own avocado tree," Lila muses. "That would be amazing," Max agrees.They hug and smile, cherishing their friendship and newfound love for avocados.', 1)
('Ben and Mia were playing in the park with their dog, Spot. They liked to run and jump and slide and swing. Spot liked to chase and bark and fetch and roll. They were having a lot of fun.But then, they saw a big hole in the fence. They were curious. They wanted to see what was on the other side. They told Spot to stay and they crawled through the hole. They found a big field with flowers and trees and birds. They felt happy.They did not see the sign that said "Beware of the Bull". They did not hear the loud moo that came from behind the bushes. They did not notice the big, angry animal that was running towards them. They were in danger.Spot saw the bull. He was anxious. He wanted to rescue his friends. He barked and ran through the hole. He got to the field and saw the bull. He was brave. He jumped and bit the bull\'s tail. The bull was surprised. He stopped and turned around. He saw Spot and was scared. He ran away.Ben and Mia heard Spot\'s bark. They saw the bull and Spot. They were shocked. They realized they were in trouble. They ran back to the hole. They crawled through and hugged Spot. They thanked him for saving them. They learned their lesson. They decided to never go through the hole again. They went back to the park and played some more. They were safe.', ' Present Tense:Ben and Mia play in the park with their dog, Spot. They run, jump, slide, and swing. Spot chases, barks, fetches, and rolls. We all have a great time.But we see a big hole in the fence. We\'re curious. We want to explore what\'s on the other side. We tell Spot to stay and crawl through the hole. We discover a large field filled with flowers, trees, and birds. We feel happy.We don\'t notice the "Beware of the Bull" sign. We don\'t hear the loud moo from the bushes. We don\'t see the big, angry animal approaching. We\'re in danger.Spot notices the bull. He\'s anxious. He wants to save us. He barks and runs through the hole. He reaches the field and encounters the bull. He\'s brave. He jumps and bites the bull\'s tail. The bull is surprised. He stops and turns around. He sees Spot and is scared. He runs away.We hear Spot\'s bark. We see the bull and Spot. We\'re shocked. We realize we\'re in trouble. We crawl back through the hole and hug Spot. We thank him for saving us. ('Anna and Ben are friends. They like to play outside. They enjoy exercise. They run, jump, and kick a ball. They are clever. They know how to share and take turns.One day, they see a big dog. The dog is black and white. It has a long tail. It looks friendly. Anna and Ben want to pet the dog. They run to the dog. They say, "Hello, dog! Can we play with you?"The dog does not like Anna and Ben. The dog is angry. It barks and growls. It shows its teeth. It bites Anna and Ben. They cry and scream. They are hurt. They are scared.A man comes. He is the dog\'s owner. He says, "Sorry, sorry! My dog is not nice. He does not like children. He is a guard dog. You should not go near him."Anna and Ben are sad and mad. They say, "You are a bad man! You should not have a bad dog! You should keep him away from us!"The man takes the dog and leaves. Anna and Ben go home. They tell their moms what happened. Their moms hug them and take them to the doctor. The doctor gives them medicine and bandages. He says, "You are brave. You will be okay. But you should be careful. Not all dogs are friendly. Some dogs are dangerous. You should always ask before you pet a dog."Anna and Ben learn a lesson. They do not enjoy exercise today. They do not feel clever. They feel sorry and silly. They wish they had not met the bad dog.', ' Anna and Ben are friends in the present. They enjoy playing outside and exercising. They run, jump, and kick a ball. They are clever and can share and take turns. Today, they notice a big dog. The dog is black and white with a long tail, appearing friendly. Anna and Ben approach the dog, greeting it with "Hello, dog! Can we play with you?"However, the dog does not like Anna and Ben. It becomes angry, barking and growling, showing its teeth, and bites them. Anna and Ben cry and scream in pain and fear. A man, the dog\'s owner, arrives, apologizing, "Sorry, sorry! My dog is not nice. He doesn\'t like children. He\'s a guard dog. You should not go near him."Anna and Ben are sad and angry. They accuse the man, "You\'re a bad man! You shouldn\'t have a bad dog! Keep him away from us!" The man takes the dog and leaves. Anna and Ben return home, informing their mothers about the incident. Their mothers comfort them, taking them to the doctor for medicine and bandages. The doctor advises, "You\'re brave. You\'ll be okay. But remember, not all dogs are friendly. Some are dangerous. Always ask before petting a dog."Anna and Ben learn their lesson, feeling sorry and disappointed. They no longer enjoy their outdoor activities today. They no longer feel clever. They regret encountering the unfriendly dog.', 1)
('Anna and Ben were playing with their toys in the park. They saw a big crane lifting heavy things. They wanted to know how it worked."Let\'s go and ask the man who drives the crane," Ben said."OK, but be careful," Anna said.They ran to the crane and saw a man sitting inside. He was wearing a helmet and a vest."Hello, sir," Ben said. "Can you tell us how you make the crane move?"The man smiled and opened the door. He invited them to sit with him."Sure, I can tell you," he said. "The crane has a motor and a cable. The motor makes the cable go up and down. The cable has a hook at the end. I use a joystick to control the hook. I can lift and lower things with the hook.""Wow, that\'s amazing," Anna said. "You must be very intelligent to do that."The man laughed and said, "Thank you, but I\'m not the only one who is intelligent. The crane is also intelligent. It has sensors and computers that help me. They tell me how much weight I can lift and how far I can move. They also warn me if there is any danger or problem.""Really? How do they do that?" Ben asked.The man showed them a screen and some buttons. He explained how the sensors and computers worked. He also told them some rules and safety tips for using the crane.Anna and Ben learned a lot from the man. They thanked him and said goodbye. They went back to their toys and pretended to be crane drivers.They had fun and also learned something new. They realized that the crane was not just a big toy, but a useful and intelligent machine. They also realized that the man was not just a driver, but a teacher and a friend. They learned to be curious, respectful, and grateful.', ' Present Tense:Anna and Ben play with their toys in the park. They see a big crane lifting heavy things. They want to know how it works."Let\'s go and ask the crane operator," Ben suggests."Okay, but be careful," Anna advises.They run to the crane and see a man sitting inside. He wears a helmet and a vest."Hello, sir," Ben greets. "Can you tell us how you make the crane move?"The man smiles and opens the door. He invites them to sit with him."Sure, I can tell you," he says. "The crane has a motor and a cable. The motor makes the cable go up and down. The cable has a hook at the end. I use a joystick to control the hook. I can lift and lower things with the hook.""Wow, that\'s amazing," Anna exclaims. "You must be very intelligent to do that."The man laughs and says, "Thank you, but I\'m not the only one who is intelligent. The crane is also intelligent. It has sensors and computers that help me. They tell me how much weight I can lift and how far I can move. They also warn me if there is any danger or problem.""Really? How do they do that?" He also tells them some rules and safety tips for using the crane.Anna and Ben learn a lot from the man. They thank him and say goodbye. They go back to their toys and pretend to be crane drivers. They also realize that the man is not just a driver, but a teacher and a friend. They learn to be curious, respectful, and grateful.', 1)
('Lily liked to do yoga with her mom. Yoga was when they made funny shapes with their bodies on a mat. Sometimes they were trees, sometimes they were cats, sometimes they were stars. Lily liked to stretch and breathe and feel calm.One day, Lily saw a big sack in the corner of the living room. She wondered what was inside. She asked her mom, but her mom said it was a surprise. Lily was curious. She wanted to see the surprise. She waited until her mom was busy in the kitchen, and then she tiptoed to the sack.She opened the sack and peeked inside. She saw lots of toys and books and clothes. They were all new and shiny and colorful. Lily was happy. She thought the sack was a gift for her. She pulled out a doll, a puzzle, a hat, and a ball. She played with them on the floor. She made a mess.Her mom came back and saw the mess. She was not happy. She said, "Lily, what have you done? This sack is not for you. It is for the children who don\'t have many things. We are going to give it to them tomorrow. You have to put everything back and make it tidy."Lily felt sad. She did not mean to be naughty. She said, "I\'m sorry, mom. I thought it was for me. I like the toys and books and clothes. Can I keep one?" Her mom said, "No, Lily. You have enough things. You have to share with others. That is what yoga teaches us. To be kind and generous and grateful. Now, help me put everything back and make it tidy."Lily helped her mom put everything back in the sack. She said goodbye to the doll, the puzzle, the hat, and the ball. She said, "I hope you make the children happy. Maybe they will do yoga with you." She hugged her mom and said, "I love you, mom. I\'m sorry I made a mess. Can we do yoga now?" Her mom said, "I love you too, Lily. Yes, we can do yoga now. Let\'s be trees." They smiled and made funny shapes with their bodies on the mat. They stretched and breathed and felt calm.', ' Present Tense:Lily likes doing yoga with her mom. They make funny shapes with their bodies on a mat. Sometimes they are trees, sometimes cats, sometimes stars. Lily enjoys stretching, breathing, and feeling calm.One day, Lily notices a big sack in the living room corner. She wonders what\'s inside. She asks her mom, but she says it\'s a surprise. Lily is curious and waits until her mom is busy in the kitchen before she tiptoes to the sack.She opens the sack and peeks inside, seeing lots of new and shiny toys, books, and clothes. Lily is happy and believes the sack is a gift for her. She pulls out a doll, a puzzle, a hat, and a ball, playing with them on the floor and making a mess.Her mom returns and sees the mess, not happy. She tells Lily, "Lily, what have you done? This sack isn\'t for you. We\'re giving it to children without many things tomorrow." Lily feels sad, apologizes, and helps her mom put everything back in the sack. She says goodbye to her new possessions and hopes they\'ll make the children happy. They do yoga together, smiling and making funny shapes on the mat.', 1)
('Lily was a tall girl who liked to eat toast for breakfast. She liked to put butter and jam on her toast and make it sweet and soft. She also liked to tell stories to her little brother, Ben, who was still in his crib.One morning, Lily woke up early and went to the kitchen. She saw a big loaf of bread on the counter and decided to make toast for herself and Ben. She took two slices of bread and put them in the toaster. She waited for them to pop up and then took them out. She put butter and jam on them and put them on a plate.She carried the plate to Ben\'s room and saw him sleeping. She smiled and said, "Wake up, Ben! I have toast for you!" She put the plate on his nightstand and climbed into his crib. She gave him a hug and a kiss and said, "Good morning, Ben! Do you want to hear a story?"Ben opened his eyes and saw Lily and the toast. He smiled and said, "Yes, please! I love your stories!" He took a bite of the toast and said, "Mmm, this is yummy! Thank you, Lily!"Lily said, "You\'re welcome, Ben! Now, listen to my story. It\'s about a tall princess who lived in a castle with a dragon. She was brave and smart and kind. Do you want to know what she did?"Ben nodded and said, "Yes, yes, tell me more!"Lily smiled and began to tell her story. She used her voice and her hands to make it fun and exciting. Ben listened and laughed and asked questions. They ate their toast and enjoyed their story. They were happy and loved each other very much.', ' Present Tense:Lily is a tall girl who enjoys eating toast for breakfast. She puts butter and jam on her toast to make it sweet and soft. She also tells stories to her little brother, Ben, who is still in his crib.This morning, Lily wakes up early and goes to the kitchen. She sees a big loaf of bread on the counter and decides to make toast for herself and Ben. She takes two slices of bread and puts them in the toaster. She waits for them to pop up and then takes them out. She puts butter and jam on them and puts them on a plate.She carries the plate to Ben\'s room and sees him sleeping. She smiles and says, "Wake up, Ben! I have toast for you!" She puts the plate on his nightstand and climbs into his crib. She gives him a hug and a kiss and says, "Good morning, Ben! Do you want to hear a story?"Ben opens his eyes and sees Lily and the toast. He smiles and says, "Yes, please! I love your stories!" He takes a bite of the toast and says, "Mmm, this is yummy! Thank you, Lily!"Lily says, "You\'re welcome, Ben! Now, listen to my story. It\'s about a tall princess who lives in a castle with a dragon. She is brave and smart and kind."Ben nods and says, "Yes, yes, tell me more!"Lily smiles and begins to tell her story. She uses her voice and her hands to make it fun and exciting. Ben listens and laughs and asks questions. They eat their toast and enjoy their story. They are happy and love each other very much.', 1)
('Lily liked to design things with her crayons and paper. She made houses, flowers, animals and people. She was very good at drawing. One day, she wanted to design a figure of her best friend, Mia. She took a big paper and a blue crayon and started to draw."Look, Mommy, I am making Mia!" she said, showing her paper to her mom."That\'s very nice, Lily. You are a great artist," her mom said, smiling. "But don\'t forget to clean up your crayons when you are done."Lily nodded and went back to her drawing. She made Mia\'s hair, eyes, nose, mouth and dress. She was very happy with her figure. She wanted to show it to Mia the next day at school.But then, her little brother, Ben, came into her room. He saw the paper and the crayons. He liked to play with them. He did not know that Lily was designing something. He grabbed the paper and the crayons and ran away."Hey, give that back!" Lily shouted, chasing him. "That\'s mine!"Ben did not listen. He ran to the kitchen and hid behind the table. He thought it was a fun game. He took the crayons and scribbled all over the paper. He made lines, circles, dots and squiggles. He ruined Lily\'s figure.Lily followed him and saw what he did. She was very angry and sad. She cried and yelled at him."Ben, you are so bad! You ruined my figure of Mia! How could you do that? I worked so hard on it!"Ben did not understand why Lily was so upset. He thought he was just having fun. He did not say sorry. He just smiled and threw the paper on the floor.Lily picked up the paper and saw that her figure was hidden under the mess. She could not fix it. She could not show it to Mia. She felt like she lost her best friend. She ran to her mom and hugged her. She wished Ben was never born.', ' Present Tense:Lily designs things with her crayons and paper. She creates houses, flowers, animals, and people. She\'s excellent at drawing. Today, she decides to make a figure of her best friend, Mia. She grabs a big paper and a blue crayon, then starts to draw."Look, Mommy, I\'m making Mia!" she exclaims, showing her mom."That\'s very nice, Lily. You\'re a great artist," her mom replies, smiling. "But don\'t forget to clean up your crayons when you\'re done."Lily nods and continues her drawing. She creates Mia\'s hair, eyes, nose, mouth, and dress. She\'s pleased with her figure. She intends to show it to Mia the next day at school.But then, her little brother, Ben, enters her room. He sees the paper and crayons. He enjoys playing with them. He doesn\'t realize Lily is creating something. He grabs the paper and crayons and runs away."Hey, give that back!" Lily shouts, chasing him. "That\'s mine!"Ben doesn\'t listen. He runs to the kitchen and hides behind the table. He believes it\'s a fun game. He takes the crayons and scribbles all over the paper. He makes lines, circles, dots, and squiggles. He ruins Lily\'s figure.Lily follows him and witnesses the destruction. She\'s angry and sad. She cries and yells at him."Ben, you\'re so bad! You ruined my figure of Mia! How could you do that? I worked so hard on it!"Ben doesn\'t understand why Lily is upset. He thinks he was just having fun. He doesn\'t apologize. He merely smiles and throws the paper on the floor.Lily picks up the paper and sees that her figure is hidden under the mess. She can\'t fix it. She can\'t show it to Mia. She feels like she\'s lost her best friend. She runs to her mom and hugs her. She wishes Ben hadn\'t been born.', 1)
('Ben and Mia are twins. They like to play with their toy cars. They have many cars of different colors and sizes. They drive them on the floor, on the sofa, on the table. They make noises like vroom, beep, honk.One day, they find a big black car in the garage. It is their dad\'s car. It looks shiny and cool. They want to play with it. They open the door and climb inside. They see many buttons and levers. They touch them and pull them. The car makes noises like click, whirr, ding."Look, Mia, I can drive!" Ben says. He turns the key in the ignition. The car starts to move. It goes forward and backward. It bumps into the wall and the shelves. It makes noises like crash, bang, screech."Stop, Ben, stop!" Mia says. She is scared. She wants to get out. But the door is locked. She cries and screams. She pushes the horn. It makes a loud noise like honk, honk, honk.Dad hears the noise. He runs to the garage. He sees the car moving and shaking. He sees Ben and Mia inside. He is angry and worried. He opens the door and takes them out. He hugs them and checks if they are hurt. He is glad they are okay. He scolds them and tells them to never play with his car again. He says it is dangerous and not a toy. He says they could have broken the car or hurt themselves or others.Ben and Mia are sorry. They say they are sorry to dad and to the car. They promise to never do it again. They learn that they should not touch things that are not theirs. They learn that they should listen to dad and be careful. They learn that driving is not a game. They go back to their toy cars. They drive them safely and happily. They make noises like vroom, beep, honk.', ' Present Tense:Ben and Mia play with their toy cars. They have many cars of different colors and sizes. They drive them on the floor, on the sofa, on the table. They make noises like vroom, beep, honk.Today, they discover a big black car in the garage. It\'s their dad\'s car. It looks shiny and cool. They want to play with it. They open the door and climb inside. They see many buttons and levers. They touch them and pull them. The car makes noises like click, whirr, ding."I can drive this!" Ben exclaims. He turns the key in the ignition. The car starts to move. It goes forward and backward. It bumps into the wall and the shelves. It makes noises like crash, bang, screech."Stop, Ben, stop!" Mia shouts. She\'s scared. She wants to get out. But the door is locked. She cries and screams. She pushes the horn. It makes a loud noise like honk, honk, honk.Dad hears the noise. He runs to the garage. He sees the car moving and shaking. He sees Ben and Mia inside. He\'s angry and worried. He opens the door and takes them out. He hugs them and checks if they\'re hurt. He\'s glad they\'re okay. He scolds them and tells them never to play with his car again. He says it\'s dangerous and not a toy. They could have broken the car or hurt themselves or others.Ben and Mia apologize. They\'re sorry to dad and to the car. They promise never to do it again. They learn that they should not touch things that are not theirs. They learn to listen to dad and be careful. They learn that driving is not a game. They go back to their toy cars. They drive them safely and happily. They make noises like vroom, beep, honk.', 1)
('Anna and Ben were at the park with their mom. They liked to play on the swings, the slide and the sandbox. They saw many other kids and some dogs too. They waved to their friends and said hello."Mom, can we have ice-cream?" Anna asked. She loved ice-cream, especially chocolate and vanilla. Ben nodded. He liked ice-cream too, but he preferred strawberry and banana."Sure, sweeties. Let\'s go to the ice-cream truck," mom said. She took their hands and walked with them to the truck. There were many flavors and colors of ice-cream. Anna and Ben chose their favorites and mom paid the man."Thank you, mom!" Anna and Ben said. They licked their ice-creams and smiled. They were very yummy and cold.As they were eating their ice-creams, they saw a little girl with a big hat and a pink dress. She was holding a balloon and a teddy bear. She looked very adorable. She waved to Anna and Ben and came closer."Hi, I\'m Lily. Do you want to play with me?" she asked. She had a friendly voice and a cute smile."Hi, I\'m Anna and this is Ben. We would love to play with you," Anna said. She liked Lily\'s hat and balloon. Ben liked her teddy bear."Great! Let\'s go to the sandbox. I have some toys there," Lily said. She led them to the sandbox and they started to make sandcastles, bridges and tunnels. They had a lot of fun and shared their toys and ice-creams.Anna, Ben and Lily became good friends. They played until it was time to go home. They hugged and waved goodbye. They promised to see each other again soon. They were very happy.', ' Present Tense:Anna and Ben are at the park with their mom. They enjoy playing on the swings, slide, and sandbox. They notice many other kids and some dogs. They greet their friends and wave hello."Mom, can we have ice-cream?" Anna asks, her eyes shining with excitement. She adores chocolate and vanilla flavors. Ben agrees, nodding. He prefers strawberry and banana."Sure, sweeties. Let\'s go to the ice-cream truck," mom responds, taking their hands and leading them towards the truck. A variety of ice-cream flavors and colors catch their attention. Anna and Ben make their selections. Mom pays the man."Thank you, mom!" Anna and Ben express their gratitude, licking their delicious and cold treats.As they savor their ice-creams, they spot a little girl in a big hat and pink dress, holding a balloon and a teddy bear. She looks charming. She approaches and waves."Hi, I\'m Lily," she introduces herself. "Would you like to play with me?" she asks, her voice friendly and her smile captivating."Hi, I\'m Anna, and this is Ben," Anna responds. "We\'d love to play with you." Ben is drawn to Lily\'s teddy bear."Great! Let\'s go to the sandbox. I have some toys there," Lily suggests, leading them to the sandbox. They build sandcastles, bridges, and tunnels, sharing toys and ice-creams. They have a fantastic time.Anna, Ben, and Lily form a friendship. They play until it\'s time to go home. They hug and wave goodbye, promising to meet again soon. They are content and happy.', 1)
('Lila and Tom were best friends. They liked to play in the park with their toys. One day, they saw some big kids coming. The big kids looked mean and angry. They wanted to take Lila and Tom\'s toys."Give us your toys, or we will hurt you!" one of the big kids shouted.Lila and Tom were scared. They did not want to lose their toys. They did not want to get hurt. They hugged each other and held their toys tight."No, these are our toys! Go away!" Tom said.The big kids laughed. They moved closer to Lila and Tom. They reached out their hands to grab the toys."Stop! Leave them alone!" a voice said.Lila and Tom looked up. They saw Sam, their older brother. Sam was strong and brave. He came to the park to protect them. He stood in front of Lila and Tom and faced the big kids."These are my sister and brother. You cannot take their toys. You cannot hurt them. Go away, or I will make you go away!" Sam said.The big kids did not laugh anymore. They saw that Sam was stronger than them. They did not want to fight him. They did not want to start a war. They turned around and ran away.Lila and Tom were happy. They thanked Sam for saving them. They gave him a hug and a kiss."You are the best brother ever!" Lila said."You are our hero!" Tom said.Sam smiled. He hugged them back. He was glad he could protect them."Let\'s go home and have some cookies," Sam said.Lila and Tom nodded. They picked up their toys and followed Sam. They felt safe and loved. They were a happy family.', ' Present Tense:Lila and Tom are best friends. They enjoy playing in the park with their toys. Today, they notice some older kids approaching. The kids look mean and angry, intending to take Lila and Tom\'s toys."Give us your toys, or we will hurt you!" one of the kids shouts.Lila and Tom are scared. They don\'t want to lose their toys or get hurt. They hug each other tightly and hold their toys close."No, these are our toys! Go away!" Tom declares.The kids laugh and move closer. They reach out their hands to grab the toys."Stop! Leave them alone!" a voice rings out.Lila and Tom look up. They see Sam, their older brother. Sam is strong and brave. He came to the park to protect them. He stands in front of Lila and Tom, facing the kids."These are my sister and brother. You cannot take their toys. You cannot hurt them. Go away, or I will make you go away!" Sam asserts.The kids no longer laugh. They realize Sam is stronger than them. They don\'t want to fight him. They turn around and run away.Lila and Tom are happy. They thank Sam for saving them. They give him a hug and a kiss."You are the best brother ever!" Lila exclaims."You are our hero!" Tom agrees.Sam smiles. He hugs them back. He\'s glad he could protect them."Let\'s go home and have some cookies," Sam suggests.Lila and Tom nod. They pick up their toys and follow Sam. ('Tom and Mia are friends. They like to play with equipment in the park. They have a slide, a swing, a seesaw and a climbing frame. They test the equipment every day. They want to see who is faster, higher, and stronger.One day, they see a new equipment in the park. It is a big net. It is made of ropes. It looks like a spider web. Tom and Mia are curious. They want to test the net. They run to the net and climb on it.The net is fun. It is bouncy and wobbly. Tom and Mia laugh and shout. They try to reach the top of the net. They test their balance and strength. They are strong. They can hold on to the ropes.But then, the net starts to shake. It is not because of Tom and Mia. It is because of a big dog. The dog is chasing a ball. The ball rolls under the net. The dog follows the ball. The dog jumps on the net.Tom and Mia are scared. The net is not strong enough for the dog. The net makes a loud noise. It breaks. Tom and Mia fall to the ground. They are not hurt. They are just dirty and sad. The dog runs away with the ball.Tom and Mia look at the broken net. They are sorry. They did not mean to break the equipment. They go to find the park keeper. They want to tell him what happened. They hope he can fix the net. They want to test it again.', " Tom and Mia are friends in the park, where they enjoy testing equipment daily. They have a slide, swing, seesaw, and climbing frame. We test the equipment together, seeing who's faster, higher, and stronger.Today, we notice a new addition: a large, rope net resembling a spider web. Intrigued, we rush to explore it. We climb, laugh, and shout as we attempt to reach the top, testing our balance and strength.The net is fun, bouncy, and wobbly. We're strong; we can hold on to the ropes. Suddenly, the net shakes. It's not us; a big dog is chasing a ball under the net. The dog jumps on the net, causing it to make a loud noise and break.We fall to the ground, unharmed but dirty and sad. The dog runs away with the ball. We look at the broken net, feeling remorseful. We head to find the park keeper to report the incident and hope for a repair.", 1)
('Tom and Lily were playing in the park. They liked to slide, swing and run. But they did not like the big tree. The big tree had a hole in its trunk. It looked like a mouth. Tom and Lily thought the big tree was scary.One day, Tom had an idea. He wanted to scare Lily. He said, "Lily, let\'s play hide and seek. You count to ten and I hide." Lily agreed. She closed her eyes and counted. Tom ran to the big tree. He climbed inside the hole. He thought, "This will be fun. Lily will be so scared when I jump out."Lily finished counting. She opened her eyes and looked for Tom. She saw his shoes sticking out of the hole. She smiled. She knew where he was. She tiptoed to the big tree. She said, "I found you, Tom. You are in the big tree." She reached for his shoes. But then, something happened.Tom heard a loud noise. He felt something move in the hole. He looked up. He saw a big, furry head. It had sharp teeth and yellow eyes. It was a raccoon. The raccoon was angry. It did not like Tom in its home. It growled and hissed. Tom was terrified. He screamed and ran out of the hole.Lily saw Tom run out of the hole. She saw the raccoon chase him. She was shocked. She did not know there was a raccoon in the big tree. She said, "Tom, watch out! There is a raccoon!" She ran after him. They both ran to the other side of the park. They did not stop until they were safe.Tom and Lily hugged each other. They were glad they were okay. They looked at the big tree. They did not like it anymore. They said, "Let\'s never play near the big tree again. It is too scary." They decided to play somewhere else. They found a sandbox. They thought it was fun. They forgot about the big tree and the raccoon. They did not try to scare each other again. They learned their lesson.', ' Present Tense:Tom and Lily play in the park. They enjoy sliding, swinging, and running. However, they dislike the big tree. The big tree has a hole in its trunk, which looks like a mouth. Tom and Lily find the big tree scary.One day, Tom comes up with an idea. He suggests playing hide and seek with Lily. She agrees. Tom hides while Lily counts to ten. Tom runs to the big tree and climbs inside the hole, planning to scare Lily.Lily finishes counting. She opens her eyes and searches for Tom. She spots his shoes sticking out of the hole. She approaches the tree, saying, "I found you, Tom." But as she reaches for his shoes, something unexpected happens.Tom hears a loud noise and feels something move in the hole. He looks up and sees a big, furry head with sharp teeth and yellow eyes. It\'s a raccoon, and it\'s angry. The raccoon growls and hisses, not happy about Tom\'s presence in its home. Tom is terrified and screams, running out of the hole.Lily watches Tom run out of the hole and sees the raccoon chase him. She\'s shocked and didn\'t know there was a raccoon in the big tree. She calls out to Tom, "Tom, watch out! There is a raccoon!" She runs after him, both of them fleeing to the other side of the park. They don\'t stop until they\'re safe.Tom and Lily hug each other, relieved they\'re okay. They look at the big tree and decide, "We\'ll never play near the big tree again. It\'s too scary." They find a sandbox and play there instead, forgetting about the big tree and the raccoon. They don\'t try to scare each other again. They\'ve learned their lesson.', 1)
('Sara and Ben are friends. They like to play with cards. They have many cards with animals and colors. They make piles and match the cards.One day, Sara finds a card that is torn. It is a card with a big lion. She likes the lion card. She is sad. She shows the card to Ben."Oh no, your card is broken!" Ben says. "Do you want to fix it?""Yes, please. How can we fix it?" Sara asks.Ben thinks. He has an idea. He gets some tape from his backpack. He puts the tape on the card. He sticks the two pieces together."There, your card is fixed!" Ben says. He gives the card to Sara.Sara smiles. She looks at the card. The lion is still there. The tape is shiny. She thinks the card is amazing."Thank you, Ben. You are a good friend. You made my card amazing!" Sara says.Ben smiles too. He is happy. He likes to help Sara. They hug. They play with the cards again. They have fun.', ' Present Tense:Sara and Ben are friends. They enjoy playing with cards. They possess numerous cards featuring animals and colors. They create piles and match the cards.One day, Sara discovers a torn card. It\'s a card with a large lion. She\'s fond of the lion card. She feels sad. She shares the card with Ben."Oh no, your card is torn!" Ben exclaims. "Would you like me to fix it?""Yes, please," Sara replies. "How can we mend it?"Ben ponders. He has an idea. He retrieves some tape from his backpack. He applies the tape to the card, joining the torn pieces together."Here you go," Ben says, presenting the card to Sara. "Your card is repaired!"Sara beams. She examines the card. The lion remains intact. The tape shines. She\'s thrilled."Thank you, Ben," Sara expresses her gratitude. "You\'re a wonderful friend. You\'ve made my card extraordinary!"Ben grins. He\'s pleased. He delights in helping Sara. They embrace. Once more, they engage in card play. They continue to have fun.', 1)
('Lily liked to write with her crayons. She wrote her name, her mom\'s name, and her dog\'s name on many papers. She also liked to draw flowers and stars and hearts. She was very proud of her writing and drawing.One day, she saw a big white wall in the living room. She thought it was a good place to write and draw. She took her crayons and started to write and draw on the wall. She wrote "Lily loves Mom" and drew a big heart. She smiled and felt happy.But then, her mom came into the living room and saw the wall. She was very angry. She shouted at Lily and said, "Lily, what did you do? You made a big mess on the wall! You are a bad girl! You have to clean it up right now!"Lily felt scared and sad. She did not mean to make her mom angry. She wanted to make her mom happy. She said, "Mom, I\'m sorry. I wanted to write and draw for you. I love you, Mom."Her mom did not listen. She took Lily\'s crayons and threw them in the trash. She gave Lily a sponge and a bucket of water and said, "You have to scrub the wall until it is clean. And no more writing and drawing on the wall, ever!"Lily started to cry. She did not want to scrub the wall. She wanted her crayons back. She wanted her mom to hug her and say, "It\'s okay, Lily. I love you, too." She wanted her mom to give her a gentle massage on her back and make her feel better. But her mom did not do that. She just walked away and left Lily alone with the wall. Lily felt very unhappy. She wished she never wrote and drew on the wall. She wished she had a different mom.', ' Present Tense:Lily writes with her crayons frequently. She writes her name, her mom\'s name, and her dog\'s name on numerous papers. She also enjoys drawing flowers, stars, and hearts. Lily takes pride in her writing and drawing abilities.One day, she notices a large white wall in the living room and believes it to be an excellent canvas. She grabs her crayons and begins to write and draw on the wall. She writes "Lily loves Mom" and draws a big heart. She smiles and feels content.However, her mom enters the living room and becomes enraged upon seeing the wall. She scolds Lily, "Lily, what have you done? You\'ve made a mess on the wall! You\'re a bad girl! Clean it up right now!"Lily feels frightened and sad. She didn\'t intend to upset her mom. She wanted to make her happy. She explains, "Mom, I\'m sorry. I wrote and drew for you. I love you, Mom."Her mom disregards her apology. She takes Lily\'s crayons and discards them in the trash. She hands Lily a sponge and a bucket of water and orders, "You must scrub the wall until it\'s clean. No more writing and drawing on the wall, ever!"Lily begins to cry. She doesn\'t want to scrub the wall. She wants her crayons back. She wants her mom to comfort her and say, "It\'s okay, Lily. I love you, too." She wants her mom to give her a soothing back massage and make her feel better. But her mom doesn\'t do that. She simply leaves the room, leaving Lily alone with the wall. Lily feels deeply unhappy. She regrets her decision to write and draw on the wall. She wishes she had a different mom.', 1)
('Tom and Mia are friends. They like to play outside. One day, they go to the creek. The creek is a small river with rocks and fish. Tom and Mia see a smooth stone. It is round and shiny. They want to touch it."Look, Mia, a smooth stone!" Tom says."Can I hold it?" Mia asks."OK, but be careful. It might be slippery," Tom says.They take turns holding the smooth stone. It feels cold and wet. They hear the water make sounds. Splash, splash, splash. They hear the birds sing. Tweet, tweet, tweet. They hear the wind blow. Whoosh, whoosh, whoosh.They are happy. They smile and laugh. They play with the smooth stone. They throw it in the water and watch it sink. They find another smooth stone and do it again. They have fun at the creek. They are good friends.', ' Tom and Mia play outside together. They visit the creek today, which is a small river filled with rocks and fish. We find a smooth, round, shiny stone. Tom exclaims, "Look, Mia, a smooth stone!" Mia asks, "May I hold it?" Tom agrees, "Sure, but be careful, it might be slippery."We take turns holding the cold and wet stone. The water makes soothing sounds: splash, splash, splash. Birds sing in the background, tweet, tweet, tweet. The wind blows, creating a gentle whoosh, whoosh, whoosh.We both smile and laugh, enjoying our time at the creek. We throw the smooth stone into the water and watch it sink. We discover another stone and repeat the process. Our friendship grows stronger as we continue to have fun.', 1)
('Sara likes to sing. She sings in the morning, in the afternoon, and at night. She sings to her toys, to her mom, and to her dad. She sings happy songs, silly songs, and sad songs.One day, Sara finds a new eraser in her drawer. It is pink and has a picture of a cat on it. Sara thinks it is very pretty. She wants to sing to it. She takes it to her room and puts it on her bed."Hello, eraser," Sara says. "You are my new friend. Do you want to hear a song?"Sara starts to sing a song about cats. She sings very loud and very fast. She sings with a smile on her face.But then, something bad happens. Her brother Tom comes into her room. He sees the eraser on the bed. He likes erasers. He thinks they are fun to play with. He does not ask Sara. He takes the eraser and runs away."Hey, that\'s mine!" Sara shouts. "Give it back!"Sara runs after Tom. She is very upset. She does not want to lose her new friend. She does not want to stop singing."Tom, stop!" Sara cries. "That\'s not yours! That\'s my eraser!"But Tom does not stop. He does not listen. He laughs and runs faster.Sara feels sad and angry. She does not know what to do. She wants her mom and dad to help her. She wants her eraser back. She wants to sing again.', ' Present Tense:Sara sings in the morning, in the afternoon, and at night. She sings to her toys, her mom, and her dad. Sara finds a new pink eraser with a cat picture in her drawer and thinks it\'s pretty. She takes it to her room and places it on her bed."Hello, eraser," Sara says. "You\'re my new friend. Do you want to hear a song?"Sara sings a cat song loudly and quickly, smiling. But then, her brother Tom enters her room and takes the eraser."Sara, this is mine!" Tom exclaims and runs away."Tom, stop!" Sara cries out. "That\'s not yours! That\'s my eraser!"Tom doesn\'t listen and continues to run away, laughing. Sara feels sad and angry, wanting her mom and dad\'s help and her eraser back to continue singing.', 1)
("Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Lily. She had a teddy bear named Teddy that she loved very much. Teddy was special to her because he was unique and no one else had a teddy bear like him.One day, Lily went to the park with her mom and she accidentally left Teddy on the bench. When she realized that Teddy was missing, she started to worry and cry. But her mom told her not to worry and that they would go back to the park to find him.Lily trusted her mom and they went back to the park. Luckily, Teddy was still on the bench where Lily had left him. She was so happy to have him back and hugged him tightly. From that day on, Lily made sure to always keep Teddy close so she wouldn't lose him again.", ' In the past, a little girl named Lily had a beloved teddy bear named Teddy. Unique and one-of-a-kind, Teddy was special to Lily. One day at the park with her mom, Lily inadvertently left Teddy on a bench. Realizing her mistake, she grew worried and began to cry. Her mom reassured her, suggesting they return to the park to search for Teddy. Trusting her mom, they went back. Fortunate was Lily when they found Teddy still on the bench where she had left him. Overjoyed, she hugged him tightly. Since then, Lily made sure to keep Teddy close to avoid losing him again.Revised present-tense version:Lily, a little girl, had a unique teddy bear named Teddy whom she adored. In the park with her mom, she inadvertently left Teddy on a bench. Realizing her mistake, she grew worried and began to cry. Her mom reassured her, suggesting they return to the park to search for Teddy. Trusting her mom, they went back. Finding Teddy still on the bench where she had left him, Lily hugged him tightly, overjoyed. Since then, she made sure to keep Teddy close to avoid losing him again.', 0)
("Once upon a time, there was a kangaroo named Joey. Joey was a big kangaroo who liked to hop and play all day. One day, Joey got lost in the forest and he was confused. He didn't know which way to go to find his way back home.Joey sat down and started to plan. He thought about the way he came and tried to remember the trees and bushes he saw. After a while, Joey figured out the right way and started to hop towards home. When Joey finally made it back home, all his kangaroo friends were so happy to see him. They asked him where he had been and Joey explained that he got lost but he made a plan to find his way back. From that day on, Joey was known as the smartest kangaroo in the forest.", " In a forest, lives a big kangaroo named Joey. He enjoys hopping and playing all day long. One day, Joey gets lost and feels confused. He doesn't know which direction to take to return home. Joey sits down and plans, recalling the trees and bushes he passed by. After some time, Joey determines the correct path and hops towards home. Upon returning, his kangaroo friends welcome him warmly, inquiring about his whereabouts. Joey shares his experience of getting lost but making a plan to find his way back. Since then, Joey is renowned as the forest's smartest kangaroo.", 1)
